# **Weight Training┃Iron Body Program Benefits**

Weight training, also known as strength training, involves using weights or resistance to build muscle and increase strength.

Some of the benefits of weight training include:

⦁ Increased muscle strength and size: Weight training can increase the size and strength of the muscles, improving overall physical performance and reducing the risk of injury.

⦁ Improved bone density: Weight training can help improve bone density, reducing the risk of osteoporosis and fractures, especially in older adults.

⦁ Improved metabolism: Weight training can increase muscle mass, which in turn can boost metabolism and promote fat loss.


⦁ Reduced risk of chronic diseases: Weight training has been shown to reduce the risk of chronic diseases such as heart disease, diabetes, and some forms of cancer.

⦁ Improved mood and mental health: Weight training has been shown to improve mood, reduce anxiety and depression, and increase self-esteem and confidence.

•




# **Weight Training┃Iron Body Program (MUST KNOW)**

> The rep range is 8-12, which means you should get at least 8 reps, but no more than 12.
> 
> If you can't get 8 reps it means the weight is too heavy. If you can get more than 12 reps, the weight is too light.
> 
> Once you've done 12 reps with a certain weight, you should increase the weight for the next set.
> 
> For example, if you bench press 40kg for 12 reps, increase the weight to 45kg and do 8 or 9 reps.
> 
> Time under tension (TUT) helps dictate the training stimulus. TUT is the amount of time your body, or a particular muscle or group of muscles, is under load.
> 
> For muscle hypertrophy you need a time between 40 and up to 70 seconds of TUT.
> 
> So if you bench press, and you normally drop the weight pretty quickly and push it back up quickly, then you might look at that as a tempo of 1010 or two seconds for each rep.
> 
> Two seconds multiplied by 12 reps equals 24 seconds of TUT. This time limits your maximum gains in muscle mass.
> 
> For bodybuilding purposes, time under tension (TUT) for each set should generally be in the 40-70 second range. Sets lasting less than 30 seconds tend to build speed, strength and power but don't build maximum muscle mass.
> 
> You need at least 40 seconds of time under tension per set to stimulate maximum hypertrophy.

•




# **Weight Training┃Iron Body Program (TIME UNDER TENSION/TEMPO EXPLANATION)**

Example of time under tension, or tempo 3-0-2-0:

> ⦁ The first number is the downward phase of the movement, also known as eccentric. You move down for three seconds.
> 
> ⦁ The second number represents the time in seconds to pause at the lower end of the movement. In this case, there is no pause.
> 
> ⦁ The third number is the upward movement, also known as concentric. In this case, 2 seconds.
> 
> ⦁ The fourth number represents the time in seconds to pause at the upper end of the movement. Again, there is no pause.
> 
> Time under tension is more important than the total number or reps.
> 
> For a tempo of 3-0-2-0, you will train like this:
> 
> ⦁ 3 seconds eccentric movement
> ⦁ 0 seconds pause after the eccentric movement
> ⦁ 2 seconds concentric movement
> ⦁ 0 seconds pause after the concentric movement

||**“Just do it.”**||
